Frame Analysis¶

class feastruct.fea.frame2d.EulerBernoulliFrame2D(analysis, id, node_ids, E, A, ixx, rho)[source]¶

Bases: feastruct.fea.frame2d.FrameElement

Two dimensional frame element based on the Euler-Bernoulli beam formulation for relatively thin beams. The element is defined by its two end nodes and uses cubic polynomial shape functions to produce analytical deformations.

Variables:
  • analysis (feastruct.fea.fea.fea) – Analysis object
  • id (int) – Unique finite element id
  • nodes (list[feastruct.fea.node.Node]) – List of node objects that define the geometry of the finite element
  • f_int (feastruct.post.results.ResultList) – Internal force vector results for an arbitray number of analysis cases
  • E (float) – Elastic modulus
  • A (float) – Cross-sectional area
  • ixx (float) – Second moment of inertia
  • rho (float) – Material density
__init__(analysis, id, node_ids, E, A, ixx, rho)[source]¶

Inits the EulerBernoulliFrame2D class.

Parameters:
  • analysis (feastruct.fea.fea.fea) – Analysis object
  • id (int) – Unique finite element id
  • node_ids (list[int]) – A list of node ids defining the geometry of the element
  • E (float) – Elastic modulus
  • A (float) – Cross-sectional area
  • ixx (float) – Second moment of inertia
  • rho (float) – Material density
get_buckling_results(case_id, buckling_mode)¶

Returns the eigenvalue corresponding to the buckling analysis defined by the analysis case id and the buckling mode. Also returns an array of eigenvector values corresponding to each degree of freedom in the finite element for the given analysis case and buckling mode.

Parameters:
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • buckling_mode (int) – Buckling mode number
Returns:

(w, v) A tuple containing the eigenvalue ‘w’ and an (n x ndof) array of degree of freedom eigenvector values ‘v’, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element and ndof is the number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
Return type:

tuple(float, numpy.ndarray)
get_dofs()¶

Finds and returns an array of global degree of freedom numbers corresponding to the degrees of freedom of the finite element.

Returns:A integer array of degrees of freedom, with a length of n*ndof, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element and ndof is the number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
Return type:numpy.ndarray
get_fint(case_id)¶

Returns the internal force vector corresponding to the analysis case id.

Parameters:case_id (int) – Unique case id
Returns:A result item containing the internal force vector
Return type:feastruct.post.results.ResultItem
get_frequency_results(case_id, frequency_mode)¶

Returns the frequency corresponding to the natural frequency analysis defined by the analysis case id and the frequency mode. Also returns an array of eigenvector values corresponding to each degree of freedom in the finite element for the given analysis case and frequency mode.

Parameters:
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • frequency_mode (int) – Frequency mode number
Returns:

(w, v) A tuple containing the frequency ‘w’ and an (n x ndof) array of degree of freedom eigenvector values ‘v’, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element and ndof is the number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
Return type:

tuple(float, numpy.ndarray)
get_geometric_properties()¶

Calculates geometric properties related to a frame element. Returns the following:

  • node_coods: An (n x 2) array of node coordinates, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element
  • dx: An array consisting of the x and y distances between the nodes
  • l0: The original length of the frame element
  • phi: The angle of the frame element with respect to the global x-axis
  • c: The cosine of phi
  • s: The sine of phi
Returns:(node_coords, dx, l0, phi, c, s)
Return type:tuple(numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, float, float, float, float)
get_geometric_stiff_matrix(case_id)[source]¶

Gets the geometric stiffness matrix for a 2D Euler-Bernoulli frame element. The stiffness matrix has been analytically integrated so numerical integration is not necessary. The geometric stiffness matrix requires an axial force so the case id from a static analysis must be provided.

Parameters:case_id (int) – Unique case id
Returns:6 x 6 element geometric stiffness matrix
Return type:numpy.ndarray
get_mass_matrix()[source]¶

Gets the mass matrix for a 2D Euler-Bernoulli frame element. The mass matrix has been analytically integrated so numerical integration is not necessary.

Returns:6 x 6 element mass matrix
Return type:numpy.ndarray
get_nodal_displacements(case_id)¶

Returns an array of the nodal displacements of each degree of freedom in the finite element for an analysis case defined by case_id.

Parameters:case_id (int) – Unique case id
Returns:An (n x ndof) array of degree of freedom displacements, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element and ndof is the number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
Return type:numpy.ndarray
get_node_coords()¶

Returns an array of the cartesian coordinates defining the geometry of the finite element.

Returns:An (n x 2) array of node coordinates, where n is the number of nodes for the given finite element
Return type:numpy.ndarray
get_nodes(node_ids)¶

Finds and returns a list of node objects corresponding to nodes with ids in node_ids.

Parameters:node_ids (list[int]) – A list of unique node ids
Returns:A list of node objects corresponding to the list of node_ids
Return type:list[feastruct.fea.node.Node]
Raises:FEAInputError – If a node with node_id cannot be find in the analysis object
get_stiff_matrix()[source]¶

Gets the stiffness matrix for a 2D Euler-Bernoulli frame element. The stiffness matrix has been analytically integrated so numerical integration is not necessary.

Returns:6 x 6 element stiffness matrix
Return type:numpy.ndarray
plot_axial_force(ax, case_id, scalef)¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotNLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the axial force diagram
plot_bending_moment(ax, case_id, scalef)¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotMLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the bending moment diagram
plot_deformed_element(ax, case_id, n, def_scale, u_el=None)[source]¶

Plots the element in its deformed configuration for either a static analysis defined by case_id, or the element displacement vector u_el. The deformation is based on the element shape functions.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • n (int) – Number of linear subdivisions used to plot the element
  • def_scale (float) – Deformation scale
  • u_el (numpy.ndarray) – 2 x 3 element displacement vector
plot_element(ax, linestyle='-', linewidth=2, marker='.')¶

Plots the undeformed frame element on the axis defined by ax.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • linestyle (string) – Element linestyle
  • linewidth (int) – Element linewidth
  • marker (string) – Node marker type
plot_shear_force(ax, case_id, scalef)¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotVLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the shear force diagram
set_fint(case_id, f_int)¶

Sets the internal force vector result for the result case defined by case_id. The argument f_int is an array consisting of the following items:

  • f_int[0]: Force in the x-direction at node 1
  • f_int[1]: Force in the y-direction at node 1
  • f_int[2]: Moment at node 1
  • f_int[3]: Force in the x-direction at node 2
  • f_int[4]: Force in the y-direction at node 2
  • f_int[5]: Moment at node 2
Parameters:
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • f_int (numpy.ndarray) – Internal force vector
class feastruct.fea.frame2d.Frame2D(nodes=None, elements=None, freedom_cases=None, load_cases=None, analysis_cases=None, non_linear=False)[source]¶

Bases: feastruct.fea.fea.Fea

Parent class for a 2D frame analysis.

Includes a method for analysis initiation and a method for adding a frame element to the analysis.

Variables:
  • nodes (list[feastruct.fea.node.Node]) – Nodes used in the finite element analysis.
  • elements (list[feastruct.fea.fea.FiniteElement]) – Elements used in the finite element analysis.
  • freedom_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.FreedomCase]) – Freedom cases used in the finite element analysis.
  • load_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.LoadCase]) – Load cases used in the finite element analysis.
  • analysis_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.AnalysisCase]) – Analysis cases used in the finite element analysis.
  • non_linear (bool) – Boolean defining the type of analysis
  • dofs (int) – Number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
__init__(nodes=None, elements=None, freedom_cases=None, load_cases=None, analysis_cases=None, non_linear=False)[source]¶

Inits the Frame2D class.

Parameters:
  • nodes (list[feastruct.fea.node.Node]) – List of nodes with which to initialise the class.
  • elements (list[feastruct.fea.fea.FiniteElement]) – List of elements with which to initialise the class.
  • freedom_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.FreedomCase]) – List of freedom cases with which to initialise the class.
  • load_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.LoadCase]) – List of load cases with which to initialise the class.
  • analysis_cases (list[feastruct.fea.cases.AnalysisCase]) – List of analysis cases with which to initialise the class.
  • non_linear (bool) – Boolean defining the type of analysis
  • dofs (int) – Number of degrees of freedom per node for the current analysis type
add_element(id, node_ids, el_type='EB2', E=1, A=1, ixx=1, G=0, A_s=0, rho=1)[source]¶

Adds a frame element to a feastruct.fea.frame2d.Frame2D analysis. Possible element types include:

  • ‘EB2’: 2 Noded Euler Bernoulli Frame Element
    • Requires E, A, ixx for a static analysis
    • Requires rho for a natrual frequency analysis, a dynamic analysis, or if body loads are used
  • ‘TM2’: 2 Noded Timoshenko Frame Element
    • Requires E, A, ixx, G, A_s for a static analysis
    • Requires rho for a natrual frequency analysis, a dynamic analysis, or if body loads are used
Parameters:
  • id (int) – Unique element id
  • node_ids (list[int, int]) – List of unique node ids defining the element
  • el_type (string) – String characterising the type of frame element
  • E (float) – Elastic modulus
  • A (float) – Cross-sectional area
  • ixx (float) – Second moment of inertia
  • G (float) – Shear stiffness
  • A_s (float) – Shear Area
  • rho (float) – Material density
create_element(element)¶

Creates a finite element and adds it to the fea class.

Creates and returns a feastruct.fea.fea.FiniteElement object ands adds it to the feastruct.fea.fea.Fea object.

Parameters:element (feastruct.fea.fea.FiniteElement) – Element to be added to the analysis object
create_node(coords)¶

Creates a node and adds it to the fea class.

Creates and returns a feastruct.fea.node.Node object and adds it to the feastruct.fea.fea.Fea object.

Parameters:coords (list[float]) – Cartesian coordinates of the node ([x, y] or [x, y, z])
Returns:Node object
Return type:feastruct.fea.node.Node

The following example creates an analysis object and creates a node at x = 1 and y = 2:

from feastruct.fea.fea import Fea

analysis = Fea()
node1 = analysis.create_node(coords=[1, 2])
get_node_lims()¶

Finds and returns the minimum and maximum x, y and z values within the current analysis.

Returns:(xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax, zmin, zmax)
Return type:tuple(float)
class feastruct.fea.frame2d.FrameElement(analysis, id, node_ids, E, A, rho)[source]¶

Bases: feastruct.fea.fea.FiniteElement

Parent class for a frame element.

Establishes a template for a frame element and provides a number of generic methods that can be used for any frame element.

Variables:
  • analysis (feastruct.fea.fea.fea) – Analysis object
  • id (int) – Unique finite element id
  • nodes (list[feastruct.fea.node.Node]) – List of node objects that define the geometry of the finite element
  • f_int (feastruct.post.results.ResultList) – Internal force vector results for an arbitray number of analysis cases
  • E (float) – Elastic modulus
  • A (float) – Cross-sectional area
  • rho (float) – Material density
__init__(analysis, id, node_ids, E, A, rho)[source]¶

Inits the FrameElement class.

Parameters:
  • analysis (feastruct.fea.fea.fea) – Analysis object
  • id (int) – Unique finite element id
  • node_ids (list[int]) – A list of node ids defining the geometry of the element
  • E (float) – Elastic modulus
  • A (float) – Cross-sectional area
  • rho (float) – Material density

plot_axial_force(ax, case_id, scalef)[source]¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotNLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the axial force diagram
plot_bending_moment(ax, case_id, scalef)[source]¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotMLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the bending moment diagram
plot_deformed_element(ax)[source]¶

Plots the element in its deformed configuration. This method adopts a linear interpolation between the two end nodes.

Parameters:ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
plot_element(ax, linestyle='-', linewidth=2, marker='.')[source]¶

Plots the undeformed frame element on the axis defined by ax.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • linestyle (string) – Element linestyle
  • linewidth (int) – Element linewidth
  • marker (string) – Node marker type
plot_shear_force(ax, case_id, scalef)[source]¶

Plots the axial force diagram from a static analysis defined by case_id. N.B. this method is adopted from the MATLAB code by F.P. van der Meer: plotVLine.m.

Parameters:
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes) – Axis object on which to draw the element
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • scalef (float) – Factor by which to scale the shear force diagram
set_fint(case_id, f_int)[source]¶

Sets the internal force vector result for the result case defined by case_id. The argument f_int is an array consisting of the following items:

  • f_int[0]: Force in the x-direction at node 1
  • f_int[1]: Force in the y-direction at node 1
  • f_int[2]: Moment at node 1
  • f_int[3]: Force in the x-direction at node 2
  • f_int[4]: Force in the y-direction at node 2
  • f_int[5]: Moment at node 2
Parameters:
  • case_id (int) – Unique case id
  • f_int (numpy.ndarray) – Internal force vector
